header.title: Who are the Romani? Europe's Ancient South Asian Transplants (History of the 'Gypsy' People)

header.postText: Who are the Romani people of Europe, and what is their connection to the continent of South Asia? Today we are going to properly discuss the many Romani groups in the European continent and elsewhere today, and their unique history that separates them from other peoples in Europe. Be sure to let me know your thoughts on the Roma people today, and as always, thanks for watching! Videos of mine referenced:  Anglo-Indians: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YdQZR... Sources: http://rombase.uni-graz.at/cgi-bin/ar... http://romafacts.uni-graz.at/index.ph... http://www.middleeastgypsies.com/

Unfortunately the sad reality is that a "Roma country" would never work due to their entire culture being somewhat "parasitic" in nature. They never actually create anything, advance anything or whatever, their culture only "works" (if you wanna call it that..) because most of the world aren't like them. They need others to actually create things, advance things, build things, run things etc. for them to essentially "leech" off of.

I'm not saying this to be mean or whatever but it's just the nature of that culture, and the relatively few Roma people who actually do well are the ones who've abandoned their culture. The culture simply is not compatible with the modern world or in any country based on rule of law.

That's also why the stereotypes about them are the same everywhere they go. Usually stereotypes tend to vary and that's often how we can tell they're just stereotypes. In the USA they have the whole "Asians can't drive." thing for example but that's not a thing elsewhere so it's pretty obvious there's nothing about being Asian that makes you an inherently worse driver. If it was true, you'd see the stereotype everywhere with Asians and cars, you don't.
On the other hand the stereotypes about the Roma/Gypsies are the exact same everywhere they go as a group, because it's all down to their very culture. It's not a matter of a small minority of them causing problems or whatever, it's the very culture. Everyone living by that culture will cause problems in the west, period.

A lot of Americans seem to have a very romanticized view of the Roma/Gypsies though, I have no clue where that comes from but I've had Americans comparing the dislike of the Romas to the 1930's Germany etc. which is insanely ignorant. The Jews were hated for who they are, the Gypsies are hated for what they do. No one gives a shit if some banker, football player or whatever originally came from a Gypsy background as the problem isn't their ethnicity. If he's successful in the western world, clearly he has abandoned his culture and then he's not a problem.
It almost seems like some Americans think the whole romantic image of a trading nomadic people traveling around in their horse carriage is actually true. lol 
Maybe it's also due to the few Roma people going to USA being the well off ones (It's expensive..) and the ones maybe trying to get a "fresh start" away from their culture.. Who knows..

No matter how much people love to scream "RACISM!" these days, this issue has nothing to do with race. Well, not for anyone but the most extreme of far-right people at least, it's all about their culture. That's also why they're not doing great (as a group) anywhere as they simply can't fit in to any modern society based on rule of law, it's impossible unless they abandon their very culture. If a Roma/Gypsy then decides to get an education, get a job, obey the law etc. like other normal people, chances are that person will be "shunned" by other Romas/Gypsies. They've never been interested in integrating in any way, shape or form. You have to remember that USA was created in less time than the Romani have been a problem in Europe. It went from no USA to the USA we know today in less time than Gypsies have been in Europe, and even way back in the day their reputation was the exact same as it is today, as the culture really hasn't changed. It's just a shitty fucking culture, no matter how much you may like their colorful dresses, the romanticized "freedom" or whatever.

People often throw the Roma and Sinti together, and in Germany both groups were officially recognised as an ethnic minority requiring political representation and there is an organisation called the Union of Sinti and Roma. The Sinti however do not associate themselves with the Roma and consider themselves to be a different ethnicity altogether. The Sinti of Germany, Holland, France and Spain usually intermarry. Sometimes they marry local non-gypsies but less often. When they do, then the following applies: If the father is a Gypsy, then all the children will be considered Gypsies. If only the mother is a Gypsy, then the children are not considered Gypsies anymore; thus their sons never can have a say among the men when deliberating some internal issue. In the language of the Sinti, the word "Rom" simply means "Human". The languages of the Sinti and Roma have similarities but they have trouble understanding each other. Sinti has many words in common with Greek.

One theory is that they were associated with  a royal court,  as musicians/dancers etc patronized by a minor king.  The king and his whole entourage undertook a westward movement of conquest, but unfortunately it didn't go well for them. After the defeat of their patron, they were in effect stranded.  It was too difficult for them to make their way back to India, so they, although badly fragmented, opted to persevere in a westward migration; hence we see these peoples spreading across Turkey and into Europe, as well as across North Africa.  All this occurred at least one thousand years ago. Linguistically they are  without doubt from Northern India. Physically, it's also very obvious. Fascinating topic!! commentThread.commentText: They are not well liked among Italians though there are Italian gypsies. If you want to insult someone in Italian because of the way they live, you call them a gypsy. In English this description conjures up the idea od freedom etc but, in Italian it is very insulting, suggesting drifters, messy, dirty people, who cannot be trusted. It is particularly insulting if applied to describe a certain type of free and easy woman who dresses and behaves a certain way. The term gypsy is also used to describe a certain way of doing business eg travelling salespeople peddling goods door to door etc. This is derogatory, too but not as derogatory as when the term describes a certain type of character who lives a highly mobile, travelling lifestyle.

commentThread.commentText:
Congratulations. This is a very well-written analysis. I live in a country with a vast Roma minority and a great part of my childhood I lived among them.
As for a possible location of a Romales country ... I think you're kidding. Even though the great powers of the world would agree to find such a place for a Roma state, this state would probably be never populated. 
As I said, I knew them well enough to say that I understood their spirit. The spirit of free people who did not like to be tied to any particular country or place or even to follow any other rules than their own local rules or customs.
Even as individuals or as small groups, they can adapt to a certain place and can remain in the area for the rest of their lives, or until they are completely absorbed by the population of that region, but as a nation, they are the embodiment of the idea of migrating people, dwells or migrate where they felt better. 
Because, for thousands of years, they were never allowed to access these things, the notions of homeland, citizenship, or civic spirit is something that most of them can perceive only at the intellectual level not emotionally, being notions, emptied of any content, and that's why I always admired them. 
They are a very resilient nation that not only did not vanish throughout history (as so many other nations did), although no one loved them, but they will probably continue to last many centuries from now on. They are like water. Very hard to contain it for eternity, the water can take so many form and aspects, being almost impossible to be destroyed.

commentThread.commentText:
At some time in India's past, there were great social and political upheavals. A class-based religion called "Varna Dharma" was founded by brahmins and a warrior-class ordained as Kshtriyas began to carve out kingdoms of their own by conquering ancient democratic states and displacing entire populations from their homelands. 
These were times of tremendous oppression and genocide. These populations sought refuge in other lands.  Any unwanted and homeless people who are driven out of their homelands will naturally become segregated and end up in poverty and criminality. Thus emerged the untouchable classes of India.
Evidently, the Romanis or Gypsies are from these native people of the Indian subcontinent who fled their motherlands in times of great turmoils. A large segment of the Naga people of Indian subcontinent have become untouchables under this Varna religion (mistakenly referred as hinduism). 
If you came across names like "naga" among the Gypsies & Romanis, you can be sure that they are of Indian origin. Recently, Gypsies in Europe rallied under the name of Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, a great intellectual who drafted the Constitution of India and laid the foundation of national currency & the Reserve Bank. He himself was from an 'untouchable' class.

Irish travellers are not a Romani people.  The are an indigenous nomadic group with their own distinct culture and identity.  Some even speak a Traveller-specific dialect of the Irish language with no linguistic connection to the linguistic traditions of the Roma.  Certainly both groups share some commonalities which stem from embracing a travelling lifestyle,  but they are not actually related.

I am originally Iraqi and Iraq had its share of gypsies. However, they are famous for being dancers. It was Saddam Hussein who gave them the Iraqi nationality. We call them 'Kawoliya.' On another hand, one famous Iraqi kawoliya is called Malayeen (Million), she is known for being a great dancer!

commentThread.commentText: Regarding the question if the Gypsies/Romani could establish a state of their own I'd say impossible. First of all the number of Gypsies/Romani in countries like Bulgaria and Turkey is much higher than recognized. One reason for this is because some Gypsies identify as Turks or Bulgarians and due to their own nation forging concerns both host countries welcome this. However, similar to the case mentioned for Romanians in the video, average Bulgarian also does not like it when a Romani claims to be an ethnic Bulgarian. In fact the situation is so complex that in Bulgaria there are ‚ÄúBulgarian Gypsies‚Äùwho speak Bulgarian only, ‚ÄúTurkish Gypsies‚Äù who speak Turkish, and other Gypsies who have their own languages. Some of these ‚ÄúBulgarian Gypsies‚Äù will admit they are Gypsies and others will claim to be ethnic Bulgarians. The same is also true for the ‚ÄúTurkish Gypsies‚Äù in Bulgaria who speak Turkish and some of them claim to be ethnic Turks while the rest will admit to being part of the ‚Äúmillet‚Äù. There are Gypsies who admit they are ‚ÄúRoman‚Äù but their numbers are dwarfed by comparison to those ‚ÄúRomans‚Äù  who claim to be ethnic Turks and the rest of the population has no issues with it.

commentThread.commentText: In Germany (and no racism here, as you might think), there was a sign put up on the border to poland, pointing out "no gypsies welcome, entering is punishable by death". This was pre-Hitler, under Imperial Law, which wasn¬¥t racist, compared to England or the US etc at that time. My great grandmother, whose family lived near the boarder, nevertheless, was kidnapped as a child (ca 4 years old) by a group of "Romani". The miller from the next village, which was approx. 5 miles away, saw her sitting and crying on a cart driven by the "Romani" and noticed her as being the daughter of one of his costumers, so she was able to be brought back by the townsmen. I do not think this was a custom, but kind of a reason why those "nomadic" people were prosecuted in such a harsh way back then in more "civilized" areas. I still remember her resemblances, which might be partially wrong after such a long time, but definetly they are chilling! Nowadays, of course, things changed, and the Tsigani or gypsies are a more or less ormalaccepted minority within most parts of Europe - but back then, things were different, and as I might suggest, not only exaggerated by our ancestors

I am Romanian too,! my 2 cents:There are more than one kind of gypsies,:
Gypsies from large cities,   and the rest,nomads ,metal workers,jewelry makers.
The only ones i was a victim of were the city,non nomad gypsies.
They are the most numerous and most criminal group of people.
I was attacked,in 1967 twice, by group of gypsies,5 or more(i was only 17 ),and use to travel from , high school in Pantelimon,to POdul Constanta din Bucuresti.
I was working in construction,and went to school,(liceu),in the evening ,at Liceul Al Sahia ,(Pantelimon),and sleep at working people dormitory,at,Podul Constanta.
The gypsies,were hiding in some woods next to ,the tram way station,and when i come down ,from tramway, at 11 pm, Nobody else ,only me, they will jump on me,and 2 of them hold my hands,one for every hand,and the rest of them check pockets and take anything of value,Money watch etc, and ,in a couple of seconds they run away .
Of course I will fight them every time, but they won,the way i told you,about blocking my arms.
One of this 2 attacks one of them hit me in the head with a heavy piece of wood,and for the first and last time in my life i have seen all kind of blue,red and white stars for a few seconds.
I do not hate gypsy people as  an ethnicity,but surely,a large percentage of them ,living in large cities,have a very criminal way of life,and refuse to do honest work,for a living.
They are no Robin Hood,they will attack rich ,or poor ,if the conditions are in their favor.
I am in America since 1982,and never been attacked,only once 3 young black tugs tried to take my bicycle,but i was ready for that fight and it was day time so,they did not go on with it.
Other wise,the tugs here broke my car window once, stole one Fuji,bicycle and one Honda moped both ,chained to trees in front of my property.
Only found chain cut ,with bolt cutter down next to tree.
But,the cops in Santa Ana California apprehended the thief,and called me to get my moped in about 7 days after it was stolen.
And in SAcramento Ca,my VW Bus broke down on freeway,and ,i left it there on side for 6 hours and some other tugs  broke in and stall a lot of it so bad ,that i only got $50 for the body,from a junk yard.
I had 2 tires cut with knife,on side about 10 years ago,by someone ,that did not like me here too.
So yes ,life is a fight,but some people make life harder than it should be.

There was a homeless crackhead wandering my neighborhood that I enjoyed chatting with. I had a crashed car in my driveway that was technically totaled because of a bent chassis, but the interior was in good shape and so was almost everything under the hood. I gave him the key to the car so he could sleep in it, and he slept in it for weeks.

One day he asked me if he could sell the car battery for some pocket money. "Sure, go ahead." Then one day, I came home from work and the car was gone. I freaked out. I found him down the block and he told me, "I saw some people towing the car away. I thought the landlords called a tow company." I made him give me the name of the tow company and he gave it to me.

commentThread.commentText:
I've only ever had two experiences with Gypsies. 1st was as a child in France visiting my grandparents every summer. Sometimes we'd notice a whole bunch of them show up out of nowhere and set up camp on the soccer field in the village not far from my grandparents house. Of course it prevented anyone from using the soccer field for the week or so that they were there. During that time you would see them skulking around the village stealing all sorts of stuff. Then once they were gone the soccer field was a total mess with garbage strewn everywhere and the grass all ripped up.

2nd was here in Canada when a few years ago some Gypsies started coming over from Romania and Slovakia. They would run various scams in Toronto, Montreal and Ottawa....maybe elsewhere too. I had an old Gypsy man with two plastic bags filled with "groceries", which were made to be ridiculously heavy and he'd come ask ask in an incomprehensible gibberish to help him carry his bags, which I did since I will always help the elderly, and then after walking a few feet away a younger guy slipped out from behind a wall and got behind me to try to pick my pocket. I caught on to him quickly enough to prevent it.

commentThread.commentText: In a small village here in Belgium, a group of Romani Gypsies settled down and made a camp on a piece of grassland. The villagers weren't happy so the mayor had to come up with a sollution. Talking with the Romani people didn't make them leave, so after a few days he decided to send a truck to the camp, in the truck there was a soundsystem and a deejay-booth. A local Belgian deejay showed up and started to play crappy Belgian carnaval-tunes (volume level 10), the mayor was convinced this would drive away the Roma. In stead they all came out of their tents and their mobile homes and they started to dance , it was a huge party. The mayor's face was priceless :) I never laughed so hard watching the journal (y)

I'm from Romania. Integrating the Romani into out society is proving incredibly difficult. They resist integration and refuse sending their many, many children to school. Instead, they teach them to beg and steal, and Romani neighbourhoods are notoriously dangerous. So the hate, although wrong, is understandable. 
The Romani are encouraged to pursue education. While Romanians have take high scores to get into good schools and universities, the Romani often have to just pass the exam with 5 out of 10 in order to be accepted. 
I'm not saying that Romania is doing nearly enough to educate them, but it's difficult nonetheless. 
P.S. the Romani that do integrate face little discrimination. Two of them are popular pop singers

Interesting

Gypsies are a true part of European Christian culture. In France they are the most christian group within the population. In Romania - the name comes from the Roman Empire, not from Romi - they used to follow localy existing churches and cultures. This is why some of them are Romanian orthodox christians, others speak Hungarian and there is even a tiny group of German lutheran Gypsies in Northern Transylvania.
This is changing, as many Gypsies now go to neoprotestant free churches, where they are treated as equals, not as bystanders.
This minority's fate seems to be a feudalistic system, where the ones on top get super rich and have extreme power over the common Gypsy. This can have a very positive side, if someone like the old Gipsy king Cioba is busy in improving the situation of his people. Serious concerns are because of marriages with very young girls and because of making children to beg from silly tourists.
The future depends - in my humble opinion - on breaking the feudalistic power of clan leaders and on getting out of the nomadic orientation. They have to see themselves as a settled down and valuable part of European society. They have to stop looking on other groups as a source of income, but have to make their income through serious business.

In some sources about religion there might be a monotheistic mountain-god or similar.
Punjab/Rajasthan seems to be the area they inhabited.
The exodus correlates with the Islamic conquest of Northern India.
They might have been of a very low caste or high caste. Or rather a high caste that somehow  was outside of that system.
The mountain-god and the high-caste-theory together with a culture where you are on the move could suggest a mountain-herding group of people.
The reason why they/we where called gypsies is because of Egypt but not because of actual Egypt but because of from my tongue "little egypt" which was basically western Greece.
It was a rich place at the time (Byzantine Empire... *coughs*)
There are stories of a people living on an island there.

Swedish Travelers came to Stockholm in Sweden 1512 (Before Gustav Adolfius).
Claiming to be a duke with company from "egypt".

They where in Denmark by 1410.

Early Swedish Travelers and later immigration of the so called "gypsies" in the 1800:s have very different cultures.

As to phenotype.
Well. I'm blue-eyed. Really white. Very dark blonde to brown hair.
Some cousins have dark skin.

The Roma peoples have been very poorly treated in Sweden.
My grandmother (born before 1900) had some child taken away from her when they tried to force them to be "swedish".
As they did with the Sami people.
They force-sterialized them. (threatened the children if they did not comply).

The big problem was that travelers or Romani where not allowed to settle down.
There where laws prohibiting it. Until very late.
My father (born -33) wouldn't approve of me outing myself as a romani descendant.
The stigma it has is really bad. Despite him also having blue eyes.

I would say the criminality came with the status and not the way around.
There where no social services and if you didn't have food you died.
They took on the jobs nobody wanted.
Including small metalwork like tinning copper pots.
Horse-trading. Selling stuff walking the road (which wasn't much like roads today and no cars).
They fought in quite a few wars for the Swedes and it seems like they where well liked as fighters.
I'm doubtful that that would be a trait in genetics although there seems to  have been quite a bit of fighting and rough living that might have made them well suited to fighting.

I sorta miss the history of my ancestors.
The language. The dances. The songs.

One of the reasons Romani where so opposed where that they where though to be spies of the Muslim Ottomans when in many cases they fled from them (or traveled with them doing what work they could).

Gypsies came in two waves into Europe. The first wave was due to Alexander the Great, who invaded Eastwards into modern day India and brought the people with him. These then settled throughout Central Europe. The ones in the Iberian peninsula came with the Caliphate, who already had gypsies within their ranks. Further waves, due to changes in European landscapes resulted in them moving around the continent however they are not Romanian, nor are they originally from the European continent. Their origins are to be found in the Indian peninsula but today's gypsies are European since they've already settled in the continent.

commentThread.commentText: There seems to be a lot of confusion about the term 'gypsy' as its used in the UK. We tend to make a strong distinction between Romani people (who are usually relatively recent comers), and gypsies (who may have been Romani at one stage in the distant past, but now are more strongly integrated into British culture, having had a long history in the country).

You do know that people can look "Irish" but not genetically be entirely that? In fact...even the Irish are not fully Irish. Or Irish at all. Ireland was not originally inhabited until humans came there from the mainland. So virtually all Irish and English are descended from ancient people who came there from somewhere else. 

Actually, Northern Irish and Scottish people have some pretty surprising genetics in some pockets of the population - some have genetic influence from Africa and Spain or as far away as Finland or even into north Asia. That is because Ireland and the UK are basically the last point of land for a long way, with nothing but ocean to the west of them, and so they became natural collecting places for people migrating from all areas over thousands of years. 

People on the fringes of the landmass always tend to be the ones where you find more interesting genetic signatures because it is where migrating people went who could go no further due to the water or due to cultural / societal barriers. That's the same reason why you find a lot of people in northeastern Europe who have some east-asian genetic heritage - including my Estonian family - even if they look fully European: northeastern Europe was the last bastion for paganism in Europe, it was more removed from the rest of Europe for a longer period of time, and it was close enough to Asia that people could migrate there over time without having to deal too heavily with the Christians in central and western Europe or the Muslim invasions in the South. Today, Finns, Estonians, Latvians, and Lithuanians, genetically, on average belong to Y-dna haplogroup N, which is an east-asian haplogroup shared with Mongolians, Chinese, etc, while almost ALL of the rest of Europe shares either haplogroup R1a or R1b as the most common in any given country. R1a is also found in India, and is associated with the rise of middle-eastern farmers who came to Europe thousands of years ago, bringing lighter skin color and farming practices with them (yeah, you heard me - the original hunter-gatherers in Europe were light brown skinned, not pale like modern Europeans). Estonia is another such pocket area where interesting genetic legacies are left: we have the highest percentage of ancient hunter-gatherer DNA and ancient paleo-Siberian asian dna of any living group in all of Europe. Why? Well, it is bounded on two sides by water, and wasn't really much on the maps of western European Christians until they began attempting to thrust their religion on us some 800 years ago. So the genetics are a leftover of ancient groups that came from the European mainland and from north Asia, while in the case of the Romani, they came from south asia and mixed with much of the European population for the past thousand  years. 

So it's not at ALL unlikely to find Romani DNA in people who otherwise look just like other Irish people.

Funny thing is, people seem to fail to realize that the Romani are no longer "Indian" - some try to categorize them as "people of color" when in point of fact, after a thousand years in Europe, inter=mixing with the populations there, they are an entirely different group and are a EUROPEAN people - a thousand years is indeed long enough for a wholly new ethnicity to be formed. Yes, they are European now, and so calling all Europeans "white" doesn't work because it ignores the history of Europe for thousands of years: Europeans are mixed with migrants from elsewhere and always HAVE been. Estonians are the only ones who retain a truly large percentage of the original hunter-gatherer population, and even THAT population was originally much darker skinned than the current population is - we know from skeletal remains and the DNA they contained that the ancient hunter-gatherer population of Europe had black hair, light brown skin and blue eyes. A strange combination, but that is what the true ORIGINAL prehistoric European looked like. A far cry from the sandy-haired, grey-eyed, light-skinned people who live there today but who still carry their genetic legacy more than any other living group. 

Likewise, it goes with the Romani descendants. Modern Romani can look for all the world "just white" but actually not be.

tl;dr: As far as gypsies are concerned, it's not the politician's fault for the state that they are in. They simply do not want to adapt because the state already gives them so much.

Those are measures implemented by politicians, even against the will of the people. There are almost no gypsy politicians in our country. As far as I am aware, there's 3 seats in the parliament for the gypsy party and the party itself only has like 4 members. As an apropos, the party was made by the self-proclaimed "king of the gypsies", whom, of course, lives in a palace full with "legitimate"  gold and luxuries that he "bought" with his "money". 
The gypsies in our country usually don't register as citizens, which is why we can barely even estimate their numbers. Rest assured though, they live pretty decent lives for non-citizens. While they aren't citizens, their children are registered, only so that their parents can collect welfare money. I've only seen a census of people on welfare from 2010, but it did say that of the people registering for welfare, 40% of them were ethnic gypsies. I can kinda attest to that since both gypsy villages that I've visited usually only have a grocery store and a bar (which of course is usually full).
Sabin `ul  Ok it means they don't have political representation, don't have citizenship, opportunities not provided to them, then what options they have?....

God Particle 
They have the option to register as citizens whenever they want. There are quite a few that do, in fact. I had several (as they are often refered to as) washed gypsies (meaning gypsies that come from self-emancipated families) and they are just like any other citizen. As far as I know, it was never prohibited for gypsies to form a political party and obtain "representation". In fact, there are probably hundreds of gypsy politicians in parties that are not self-proclaimed "gypsy parties", such as the Social-Democrats or the National-Liberals. Even in The New Right and the Save The Family Union I've seen a few gypsies.
As far as opportunities go, the only obstacle they face is their bad reputation, which they make a very good job of reinforcing, not only here, but abroad as well. Even the government stepped in (as I've mentioned in the first post) to help them by giving away free education and free learning materials (such as books, notebooks, backpacks, money, etc.) and they abused the system so much that it became a national joke for about a year (about how they stole school supplies, collected the money and never returned while there are kids in rural areas who have to walk kilometers to schools each day and sit in freezing classrooms). There was also a campaign to give jobs to gypsies, which was abused a lot in the beginning, but now some of them have started showing up to work. Unfortunately, the ones that do want to work mostly qualify as street cleaners.
The situation is very complicated, but it's something that they bring upon themselves and they certainly had and still have a lot of options to get out of.

Let me tell you my story about gypsies here in Romania:

I was born in an average size town in Romania (Satu Mare), a town with Romanians, Hungarians, very few Germans and some gypsies. I was both fortunate and unfortunate to witness a communist period, a long transition period to democracy and then the still going process of the Romanian society away from communism. My parents are still working although my mother is retired after 40 years of working and my father is also close to retirement age (he works since he was 16, so for 45 years already).

The first encounter with gypsies as I remember it was as small child, some gypsies came about once a week or every second week in our neighborhood screaming that they trade new pots for old clothes. This didn't have much effect on me; I rather found it a bit strange.
Then, as I grew up I started to meet more and more in different occasions. Just around the corner, close to my building, there were some gypsies selling chewing gum from Hungary directly on the street. It was funny for me to see that when a police car came, they pretended they actually are walking in that area. I also had a colleague in school for a year or so. She was put alone in a bench because she had lice. Still, we tried to play along; a colleague brought her food every single day so I can't say she was discriminated in any way.

As a child, the curiosity makes you think more and more why some people are different and you just ask. I knew that the gypsies are for instance good craftsmen; they were good in working with metal. I asked my father why his company is not hiring gypsies and the answer was surprising. They are not reliable. They don't stay in one place to work every day, they don't respect a schedule so they refuse being hired. Wow!

During vacations, I used to go for two weeks every summer to Baia Mare, a nearby town. I saw there an attempt to integrate them. They received apartments in a brand new building. The result: after one week, they burned all the available wood (parquet, doors and windows frames) in the middle of the rooms. I even heard about a horse looking outside a window at the third floor.

Then the communism collapsed (I was 12) and the Romanian society transformed. All at a sudden, new "businessmen" appeared: more or less smuggling things over the border, Ukrainians selling things (we called them Russians) in the markets, small shops selling everything from socks to TVs in 10 square meters etc. In this environment the not so legal business started to boom.

I need now to point out some differences between what we (Europeans in general) call "normal" values and what the gypsies are doing. 

1. Family
It is quite common to arrange the marriage of their children at young age. They "promise" the children to each other when they are born and by the age of 9 in some cases they actually marry them to each other. This lasts for years and there is nothing really that can be done by authorities.
As a consequence, they have children early in life, most of the time more than 4-5 of them. At this rate, they overwhelm the local population. Having children alone is not a problem, but as they don't work (see point 3), WE PAY for their allowance, medical care and so on.

A very important thing for them is to brag and to show off. See the competition for houses, cars or gold. A new "architectural style" appeared in Romania in the last years: the "towered" palaces. The number of towers shows how important you are. They actually live in a small house, in the back yard but the house must be as big as possible.

2. Education
In our society, we are advised and sometimes pushed to go to school, to study, to get a good education in order to have later an "easier" life, a good job, good money and so on. This comes along with a commitment to school, to a fixed schedule, homework, competition with colleagues for "who's the best" and so on.
First of all, the gypsies are refusing to let their own children in school. A friend of mine's mother is a school teacher. She told me that she had a gipsy girl in her class, but her parents didn't let her to study more than four years, claiming that for a girl, it's enough to be able to read and write. 
This tells a lot about their mentality. What kind of a job will her able to have later? What will she teach her children?

3. Working
The normal expectation from an adult is to have a job, to keep it and to support his/her family with his partner. This comes with social security payments, retirement plan, insurances of all kinds, plan the children development, care about their education and so on.
The gypsies, in their vast majority don't work (at least not with a contract). In Romania, they represent 10% or so from the population. I personally know only one (actually half gipsy) that had a good education and works just like any of us. I am able to bet 1000 EUR that more than 80% of the adult gypsies never worked a single day in their life (with a working contract). In the countryside sometimes they work the fields (one day deal with a farmer).
So the question comes: if they don't work, how do they earn their living? Some of them have huge houses and yet they are illiterate. How is this possible?

And the answer is very interesting.
They somehow "sneak" along our society. Our very society that condemns me for writing this text.
Stealing, begging networks, human trafficking, cheating are some of their major income sources.

Let me explain.

They are stealing by any thinkable and unthinkable methods. An example: they put a child in a big bag inside a bus along with the other luggage. The child got out, had plenty of time to search the other bags and upon arrival, he went back in his hiding place.

There are small communities of gypsies in Romania that live at the edge of villages. Of course, they don't actually own land; they manage to survive by stealing from farmers. From time to time, the farms gather, burn some houses in revenge because they can't stand any more. The result: the farmers are facing charges of discrimination and have to pay money to the gypsies. The next day, the gypsies laughed at them. The victims are now happy that they will actually get money from the sufferings they endure.

There is one place near Iasi called Podu Iloaiei, where there is a train station. It was quite common that the gypsies storm in the train, rob the passengers and leave. I don't know how it is today, but a few years ago at least it was like this.

Lately, they make a living by selling old metals to recycling companies. So they take it from wherever: metal doors from buildings, steal old iron from the very storing area they re-sell it to. But worst, they sold as old metal bombs from WWII, they stole safety equipment from the railroad network and trains derailed because of this causing deaths and huge costs. They got the equivalent of a few EUR and in exchange people died and also made a hundreds of thousands EUR damage.

Just to prove again (if needed) that they actually don't work, imagine that from time to time, one gets sick and goes to the hospital. All his/her relatives go to the hospital and stay there for hours in front, making noise, eating seeds and disturbing everybody around. If you see a big number of gypsies in front of a hospital, you can be sure that one of them is there.

Begging networks.
Don't be fooled by the poor woman with a child in the tram in Brussels (there I personally saw many beggars). Or the poor old lady at the corner saying she needs money to eat. They never actually worked and never will. YOU WORK FOR THEM. See the houses they built in Romania. Just google "palate tiganesti romania" and go to pictures.
I personally saw deliberately crippled children begging (the worst was on the train Timisoara - Satu Mare, a girl having the knees turned 180 degrees. just horrible).

Human trafficking
This is mainly done by gypsies and the gypsy women are not victims in this case. Read the book "Zu verkaufen: Mariana, 15 Jahre" wrote by Ianei Matei on this subject.

Cheating
The best example is the "deal" made by the French authorities to pay some money if the return to Romania. They took the money, returned for a nice vacation paid by the French citizens and then they returned.

They also claim they can put spells; they can "un-spell" a curse from you and so on. They can read the future and they can make anything if you just pay.


5. Interacting to the "other" society
Although all the other points touched already this point, I would like to emphasize some other aspects. 
When it comes to physically interact with them, the things start going bad. If you have a Gipsy family in your neighborhood you'll know what I mean.
In Timisoara, there were situations when such a family moved and the other families were "forced" to move out and to sell their apartments to other gypsies (at a "fair" price, of course). If your neighbors flood your apartment twice a week, have parties daily, ** on your door... you just move out.

I saw once a thing that let me breathless: in the Timisoara city center, 10 meters away from the Opera House, a Gipsy woman pulled a bit her long skirt, spread the legs and pissed from standing position. It's a pedestrian area; it was summer, daylight... UNBELIVEBLE.

A Hungarian TV crew wanted to make a show about a Gipsy village in Romania. They were surrounded and everything in their pockets was taken away. This is also shown on video. Later their local leader asked them to return everything and I believe they did it.

Recently in Craiova a woman was hit by a car. Nothing special, except that all at a sudden some gypsies came up and took everything from poor woman's purse as she was lying on the street. Can you imagine this? It's shown on video.


I rest my case here.

Facts about Roma that you don't want to hear:
They do in fact have a culture of squatting, begging, scamming, stealing and prostitution, and it's part of their culture to "teach" these topics to their children and family. On top of that, they are very loud, treat public areas as their living room and toilet, and often settle their family disputes right on the street to the complete embarrassment of anyone who passes by. 

A lot of them have no wish to work, and if they do, they don't pay taxes. Yet a very large percentage of them are on some kind of welfare. Worst of all, some of them still practice the absolutely revolting tradition of maiming their own children so that more people will take pity on them when they are forced to go begging for their parents ‚Äì if they're not just put directly into child prostitution...

True, these cultural traits may have evolved through hard times, but it doesn't exactly make them very endearing. In other words, there is a good reason for why they have such a bad reputation. 

Because of this, and because the countries where they come from are already poor, the natives in these countries are in complete despair when the EU gives way more grants directed towards helping Romani than the rest of the population, who are also struggling. Simply put, natives don't want the Roma population to grow, as it will only mean more crime and a heavier tax burden on the rest of the population.

However, to not end on a completely depressing note, those of them who do work, are well-respected for their craft, and they often become beacons in both their own villages and beyond. They are still sought after for their proficiency with blacksmithing and brickwork, for instance. More and more of them are also discovering that participating in "civilised" life gives them a far better life than if they kept their "traditional" lifestyle. Lastly they also have some absolutely fantastic musicians.

It's also the main "explanation" for anything anyone on the globe who isn't VERY CLEARLY white does. Someone in South America does something? "What do you expect, they're all gypsies." Someone in Serbia does something? "What do you expect from gypsies?" Someone in India does something? "They're gypsies, they don't know any better." 

There's rather good reason to believe there wasn't that much Nazi'sm around here as much as conviction that anoyne who looked even vaguely Mediterranean or Asian "was a Gypsy and thus up to no good". I explain to you all who are the gypsies. Two months ago my grandma had her two gypsies breaking into her home. She was sleeping, and the two went directly to her bedside table to look for gold. Of course, coming from a family of poor farmers, she is not a wealthy woman herself, yet she is weak and 95 years old, which makes her a wonderful target for these people.
She woke up while they were rummaging through her belongings, so she saw the faces of a man and a woman, seeing clearly who they were. In that moment they took a tissue dipped in some chemical agent, stuffed it onto her mouth and nose and knocked her unconscious. She woke up vomiting, with all the few valuables she had taken. The only gold she had were four medals of my deceased grandfather, one he received for surviving Mauthausen concentration camp, one he received when he was a partisan, and two for helping establishing a bank for poor farmers after the war. They even broke her ring finger, trying to rob her of her wedding ring, which she never took in almost seven decades.
This all happened in broad daylight, in the countryside near Venice(IT). Of course two gypsy women came each day for two weeks to park their car near the house before that day, chatting with each other, studying the place.
The result is a 95 year old woman in hospital for one month for the injuries, crying every day because she had some of the most touching mementos of the man she loved all her life taken away from her, all just because she is weak and those people can't be bothered to work to make money, everybody calling her "racist" because she doesn't pledge her everlasting love to them.

Good explanatory video, only a few remarks to add:
1. I don't hate the Gypsies, I hate when the confusion is made between their new name and Romanians, the people of Romania, the country.
2. The term Romani (with the accent on the final i, not as you used it in the video) is newly created. It is the political correct version of traditional names used by the rest of the world and themselves to designate Gypsies, Tzigoyner, Tsiganne, Zingaro or whatever people used to call them throughout Europe.
3. It is the equivalent of "African American" or "Native American" introduced only decades ago in public vocabulary and later enforced by censors. Except, in real life, I have never met anyone, except the douche bags working in NGOs or politicians, to actually use this PC term. Not even Gypsies themselves use Romani to refer to themselves when talking to foreigners.
4. It is true, that in their language they do use something that sounds like this. But that is from what I know derived from some Sanskrit word meaning "human" and "us / our nation". The word is something like "drom" and evolved into "rom".
5. The name Romanian (in original, rom√¢n, with the plural ‚Äûrom√¢ni") on the other hand, referring to the inhabitants of Romania (Rom√¢nia) obviously comes from Rome and the ancient Roman Empire. The place was part of that empire and the language of the country is a Latin language, very much related with Italian, Spanish, French and Portuguese.
6. Ethnically, the people of Romania and the Gypsies are also distinct. Romanians are white, European (ranging from a Mediterranean aspect with black hair and darker skin to white skin and blond hair, as numerous populations from Slavs to migratory tribes or settlers from distant parts of the empire were added to the mixture), while the Gypsies are of Indian origin (so typically have brownish skin).
7. Why the Gypsies are also diverse in aspect has another explanation. In time, it became more of a social stigma, a class. So many from the lower ranks of society would join them in the way a young man from a decent family today would become a homeless for various reasons. So you would have European individuals who would become nomadic and live among Gypsies. Or marry with them. Thus the explanation of the few Gypsies with white skin, blue eyes and even blond hair. 
8. As you point it out, in all countries, Gypsies are a slim minority. In Romania, according to official statistics, they make up 2.5% of the population. Indeed, they must be more than that, but not more than 5-10%. Thus, it is unjust to maintain the confusion of Romania as "the country of the Gypsies", inaugurated some 20 years ago when the term Romani was adopted by European Union for Gypsies.
9. It is interesting to note why there are many Gypsies in countries of East Europe. I heard a Gipsy saying this is an indicator of the tolerance of a country. Indeed, they are not an easy neighbor to have so I understand why many may not want them around. So the countries in which they are in small numbers are the ones that persecuted them the most. Thus the most racist, who now point their fingers to East Europe for having too many of them or for not integrating them properly. There is a big difference between Western types of organization and empires and the ones in the East. The Ottoman Empire, the Byzantine and the Tsarist Russian empire were all quite relaxed or incompetent in enforcing a single way of conduct. They could be violent at times, but in general let the societies bellow follow their own ways. Which was not the case with the Habsbourgs or the German administration, that was more rigorous in imposing their rules.

replies.commentText: I don't know of any extensive genetic study on either Gypsies or Romanians.

Any link to the source of that picture? I see lists of all European countries. I doubt that such large investigations have been made on the whole continent, in each country. In general, I'm skeptical about DNA studies. https://www.realclearscience.com/blog/2016/02/your_ancestry_is_about_as_informative_as_your_horoscope.html 
Even presuming the chart would have the data to back it, what it would show is that the Gypsies are the only European group that has a significant connection with Indians and Pakistanis. Which does not come as any surprise. And that they are not identical to Indians, which again is not something unexpected. They've been in Europe for a millennium, and as I point out, they've been a social class for a while, in a way still are. The Hungarians, who originate in Asia, near Caucasus, are not the same now as the tribes of the Huns or as modern people living in Kazakhstan or Uzbekistan maybe. The modern Bulgarians got their name from a Turkic tribe, the Bulgars, but are now obviously Slavic.  And so on for those who emerged from Germans, Goths, Celts, Vikings or whatever.

DNA argument seems to me too close to racism. Races exist, but it's not all that matters, at least for me, not among the first. Humans are not just breeds of dogs or other animals to be defined in such a simplistic way. Culture is far more important, religion, language, education, personal qualities, upbringing and so on. The problem with the Gypsies is not that they come from outside Europe, is that some of them did not adhere to the European culture and way of life in the last thousand years. If they did, no one would care.

Trying to remake the genealogy of a person based on genes is based too much on speculations. They say that going back a millennium would give a person something like 100.000 ancestors. What difference does it make if one of those is Alexander the Great? Though it would be cool to present yourself as his grand-grand....son. Or, let's say they find out a Persian gene in you. It would make a difference if that comes from a king or his slave, but the gene would not show it. Einstein and the woman who was doing his laundry had probably the same marker of origin. It's like with those who pretend to have lived other lives - they are always Cleopatra, Caesar, never some low life in their stories.
And what would the "European" marker indicate? A Bulgarian is not the same as a Portuguese. But many of the peoples of Europe came from Asia. If the Huns came in the 4th century, a Hungarian today would have similar indicators as someone who just moved in the 19th century to UK from Azerbaidjan and mixed with locals. But they are culturally worlds apart.  Many people will say, OK, but it's the overall percentage that matters. Well, they say we have over 90% common genes with some animals, but the small part makes a whole difference.

commentThread.commentText:
To all those who spill their opinions without knowing the history of my people:
 Yes the name for the country "Romania" is from the 19th century due to the fact that the territories inhabited by Romanians where split in 3 and ruled by different empires throughout the ages (Cuman Kingdom, Bulgar Empire (Turkic), Bulgarian Empire (Slavic), Hungarian Kingdom, Ottoman, Habsburg and even Russian Empires), so until then the term was used only for the South as Romanian Land ("Teara Romanesca"); modern speech "Tara Romaneasca"). 

 The modern term "Romanian" as in the people (" Roman" or "Ruman") however is a much older term attested in Romanian from the oldest inscriptions in the 15th century and much earlier in Greek and Roman sources as "those who called themselves Roman but are not from the Roman Empire" or "the shepherds of the Romans". The term "Ruman" originates in Transilvania, and was also used in the South and in Moldova (with the term "Moldovean" used mostly as a regional designation rather than national identity . The people living in Transilvania,  although formed an absolute majority, did not enjoy any rights and weren't even considered citizens by the German and Magyar ruling class, they were not allowed to live in Towns and were relegated to the farms as serfs. That's why later the term was replaced with "Roman" while "Ruman" remained in use to mean only serf or bondsman.

It is worth noting that "Vlach" in any form is an exonym only, and was never adopted by the Romanian people to describe themselves. It is not considered derogatory but rather wrong, since the term is Germanic for "Celt" or "neighbor of Germans", and we've never identified as either one. Today, Vlach instead of Romanian is used only in official data and censuses in countries that have appalling conditions for minority rights recognition such as Serbia and Greece). The Romanian people used the term "Vlach" only when dealing with foreigners. While the term or a variation of "Wallachia" for the south of Romania was also only used in dealings with foreigners. It is similar to how other people call Greeks "Greek" even thought the Greeks call themselves "Hellenes".

Where are Romanian people from?
One, known as the Daco-Roman continuity theory, posits that they are descendants of Romans and Romanized indigenous peoples living in the Roman Province of Dacia, while the other posits that the Romanians are descendants of Romans and Romanized indigenous populations of the former Roman provinces of Illyria, Moesia, ...

What was Romania called before it was Romania?
Antiquity. Ancient Romania was inhabited by Thracian tribes. The Greeks called them the Getae, the Romans called them Dacians, but they were actually a single Geto-Dacian people.

Why is it called Romania?
The name of Romania (Rom√¢nia) comes from the Romanian Rom√¢n, which is a derivative of the Latin adjective Romanus (Roman). Romanians are a people living in Central and South-Eastern Europe speaking a Romance language.

Are Romanians and Romans the same?
The theory of Daco-Roman continuity argues that the Romanians are mainly descended from the Daco-Romans, a people developing through the cohabitation of the native Dacians and the Roman colonists in the province of Dacia Traiana (primarily in present-day Romania) north of the river Danube.

What is the ethnic group of Romania?
About 89.4% of the people of Romania are ethnic Romanians, whose language, Romanian, is an Eastern Romance language, descended from Latin with some Bulgarian, Serbian, German, Greek, Hungarian and Turkish borrowings.

commentThread.commentText: I was recently a peace corps volunteer in Albania, and one thing I would point out is that in Albanian culture, the Romani sub divide themselves into the "egyptian" and "romani" groups. At least in the region I was in (Korca), they spoke slightly different dialects and the "egyptians" tended to really buy into the egyptian identity. I met many of them sporting egyptian themed jewelry and tattoos, for example. In general, these two groups don't get along, and the "egyptians" tended to consider themselves of a higher class than the other romani, and I heard reports of the two groups not getting along even though both were generally discriminated against equally by the dominant (albanian) culture.  *disclamier: I didn't not work directly with either community, and a lot of my information comes from over volunteers who did. I would be fascinated if anybody else has further insight into this - Please feel free to respond to this comment. Thank-you.

commentThread.commentText:
I need to point out though, Mason, that a direct and unquestionable link between the Irish Travellers and the India-derived Gypsies has yet to be established. Which is of course not easy seeing as they are both groups that are not particularly willing to participate in any sort of genetic research. But from what we now know, the ITs are almost undistinguishable from the indigenous Irish, they are also of predominantly Celtic stock. In fact, just googling their pictures tells you as much: remove the tacky tracksuits and fancy dresses, replace them with some regular clothing of an average middle-class Dublin family and nobody would know any better. It's also important to remember that the ITs have been attested in Ireland as early as the 1300s, which is some 300 years before the India-Gypsy migration to the British Isles.

Now granted, their vocabulary is in some 10% of Romani origin, however the most plausible explanation would be that the India-Gypsies simply assimilated into a greater Celtic IT community and that's the reason for the numerous Romani loanwords in their language.
The Irish Travelers are Romani?
The last I heard, genetic evidence showed pretty  that Irish Travelers are simply a branch of ethnic Irish that separated from others a long time ago, not Romani.

This is evident in written records: at first the Gypsies were perceived as a colorful minority, they were often invited to play music at weddings and even engage in fortune telling for the blast of it. But when people caught on to the fact that their purses tended to mysteriously disappear after encountering the Gypsies and that trying to confront them about it would usually end in tears, well, that's when the persecution started.

The situation in Bulgaria is basically the same as everywhere on the Balkans but in some aspects it's much worse. In particular, there is a significant number of municipalities in the country where the population has dwindled significantly over the past few decades due to mass emigration and economic decline. The demographical gap created by these negative processes was filled up mainly by RABBITly growing Gypsy communities. Unfortunately, thanks to their breeding habits, they have severely outnumbered the locals in many places. The locals, who are predominantly elderly people, suffer daily from criminal atrocities perpetrated by members of the so-called "Romani tribe" - mainly burglaries, which, at times, result in violent beatings of old men and women, who initially refused to let go of their money and other valuables willingly. Moreover, this situation has turned into a never-ending nightmare for the aged inhabitants, since almost none of them have  nearby any younger relatives to rely on, and the number of policemen, assigned to patrol around the villages, is highly insufficient. 

So, tell me, please, how is it possible not to harbour a certain degree of animosity towards the ethnic group in question? By the way, the situation I described is just a small fracture of the whole picture called "Problems we have with our dark-skinned brethren".

Romani also comes from Rome.  The original Romani were enslaved by the Seljuk Turks who eventually ended up in Asia Minor (modern Turkey) with their Indian slaves. At the time Asia Minor was part of the Byzantine Empire, but that's what we call them in the West.  The Byzantines considered themselves to be Roman, so the official name of the Byzantine Empire was the Roman Empire. Eventually the Sultanate of Rum seceded from the Seljuk Empire.  As much of their territory was conquered from the Byzantines (or the Romans), they took the name Rum.  The Romani people also took their name fro the Sultanate of Rum.  So in a very indirect way, the Romani are also named after the Romans.

Usually in the Indian culture the man has to pay for the wife and take her to his home to live with his family.  Same for Roma people. Also Romanians have a novel about a peasant who marries a woman for financial reasons. It is named "Ion" by Liviu Rebreanu. Aromanians speak a dialect of Romanian that is over 95% mutually intelligible in written form with Romanian (about 80% during speech because of the accent difference). So, no, they can't be different people. 
Also in Greece they call Aromanians "Vlahii ; Mavrovlahii or Cutsovlahii'' , so it's self explanatory. 
If they where Illyrians then they would have developed a  language breaking away directly from Vulgar Latin rather than Romanian and it would have resembled the Dalmatian language. Also, Aromanian only has negligible Slavic words , so no slavic connection there. Actually, in Romania we say that Aromanian is Romanian without the Slavic words (10% Slavic vocabulary in Romanian (less than 5% in modern speech) and less than 2% in Aromanian). They are the descendants or Romanian shepherds seasonally migrating with their flock throughout the Balkans, most of which eventually abandoned the trade and settled down in other Ottoman-controlled territories in Europe . It's true, though, that phenotypically they resemble more with Greeks than Romanians. 

Another group of people are the Istro-Romanians, they also inhabit ancient-Illyrian lands, now part of Croatia. Their origin is well known, they are farmer-migrants from Banat region of South-West Romania who settled in the Istrian peninsula in 2 waves, the first around 900 A.D. attested by works of Emperor Constantine VII and a second larger wave after the Black Death wiped out many inhabitants of the area in the 1300 A.D. This dialect has many Slavic words in it's vocabulary and is also the farthest-away from modern Romanian, due to it's speakers being isolated from other Romanian speakers throughout the centuries. Due to their much smaller numbers and isolation they have mixed with Slavs profusely and are nowalmost extinct.  It's debatable whether or not it's a dialect or a different language, but both Romanian and Croatian authorities consider it to be a variant of Romanian.

Also, Romanians of Maramuresh, Northern and Central Transylvania , Banat and Moldova are more related to Aromanians than to Romanians from Oltenia and  Muntenia and Southern Transylvania, even if the language had evolved and we understand more better the last ones. 

I think there wore some differences between regions of Roman Empire in terms of natives, Getae and Thracians of the East and Dacians and Dardanians of the west. when they took the language,  different sources and the time they took it.

For example the east(not including Moldovans who are in fact western Romanians from Maramuresh) say ‚ÄùvarzƒÉ‚Äù to cabbage, while the west or the north say curechi, curet'i. 
From that we can see the western part, Dacians and Dardanians took Latin more early then the East, Getae and Thracians, because varzƒÉ comes from green ‚Äùviridis‚Äù-‚Äùvir(i)dia‚Äù who  had the meaning of cabbage a bit latter, while curechi from vulgar  coliculus from classical   cauliculus  was the word for cabbage as a base 
(l-r shift,  drop of the termination , change of i to e will give an early curecu in western Romanian,  who would palatalize c   and would force u to drop and will make C to sound t' or chi having today curechi(more fluent) and curet'i more old.
But is good to know that dialects of the Romanian, North and South of Danube,  appeared late in the game, before that there wore just some minor difference in terms of vocabulary like the one mentioned above and some verbs from region to regions, but wore no difference in the shape and pronunciation. 

So there was no difference in the form of the words like today.  Picior was picior in all  Romanian, but palatalization in the west was more strong than in the east, maybe because the west was mixed with Illyrians in Dardania and Dacia had tons of Illyrian and Pannonian colonists (we see this to our extinct relatives, the Dalmatians, who  wore Illyrians  and had even more consonants palatalized than us, so  we must conclude that is and Illyrian feature) so picior becomed pt'icior(today Maramuresh), then P dropped in XVII century because of use and t shifted to C or ch(common to Romanian) in Moldova and in Aromanian lands. 
Also Ar√¢m√¢n is not native name, the native form was R√¢m√¢n.
So the statement that  Aromanians are not Romanians can come only from an ignorant of Romanian language and culture. 
So yes,  at the core, Romanians split in two,  the western branch, who are the heirs of Dardanians and Dacians,  and the east branch,  who are the heirs of Tharcians and Getae.
 And this is not necessary a ethnic split of the natives(because Dacians and Getae  wore one and the same people(in South Danube both wore called Moesians), maximum they spoke different dialects because  Dacians wore Getae influenced by Pannonian dialect of the Illyrian language, and Dardanians wore Tharacians and Dacians influenced by Illyrian language, but is a split because of the spread from west to east of the Latin language who took some time and needed to cross the Carpathians and Haemus and Rila mountains.

Kinda, but we were also targeted for genocide (twice), are still segregated, no one cares about us, are literally the most Whitewashed group in Hollywood (even non-White people parade around on screen as us), and are arguably, very genetically different from many of our ancestors. That being said, we are actually not "Indian". We left India 1,500 years ago, and even though we usually possess 25% to 75% South Asian heritage, we are a distinctly European peoples. (I use "peoples" because we are comprised of numerous sub-groups and each group has varying degrees of Whiteness and Brownness. Calling us Indian is like calling a Sephardic person only Middle Eastern & North African, instead of mixed Spanish and pre-European Jewish. At the end of the day, the Sephardi are distinctly European, whilst still being of non-White Jewish heritage, but are usually seen as White and European because of their considerable Iberian heritage. We too, are arguably White and are never 90% Indian the same way that African-Americans can be 90+% Sub-Saharan African. Like, you don't have to be bi-racial or have had a White slave master ancestor to be African-American and conversely, you don't have to even be the descendant of an American slave (e.g., Haitian, Brazilian, Puerto Rica, etc.) to be Black, and even some cases African-American. If you're Black, you're still Black and aren't entirely separate from your pre-slavery ancestors. Also, calling us Indian would mean that all Desi people living in Europe and facing discrimination would also be considered Romani, which just isn't the case. commentThread.commentText:
Europeans have for hundreds of years harassed the Romani and denied them equal positions in our society, and then after treating them like that for some centuries we blame them for the non-integration we forced on them(just scroll through all the negative comments here and see for yourself).

Yet I have several Romani descendant friends who've had to tell me of their origin before I knew, they were as integrated and Norwegian as anyone else. The old Romani population here is more or less completely integrated by now, it's the never arrivals from Russia the past century, and now in later years from Balkan, which are not.

And seeing that they can do, and does do, well in Latin America, it's obvious to me it's the treatment they have received that is the cause of their problems, and not the other way around. If you treat someone as shit for years and years, guess what will happen to them. You try doing that to anyone and the result will be pretty sad, try it on your own child of you want to test it out, all humans are results of our surroundings.

Taken for example African American. The crime rate among African American is higher than any African country, with the exception of Lesotho, Namibia and South Africa(which by the way is probably the three countries where the colonial rule and Apartheid had the most oppressing results). So obviously it's the treatment of African American which is the cause of their high crime rate, and not genetics. This is as evident as it gets. And the same goes with the Romani.

It's the people who write hateful comments here about the Romani, which is exactly the cause for the problems from the Romani. These haters are in essence shitting on their own legs, in a wider context. What a bunch of fucking idiots.

Please think about that the next time you decide to stigmatize and spread hate towards a group of people. You are making the world a worse place, in a direct way. Racist people are fucking cancer to society.

I found this thread pretty interesting to read through. My own experiences with Romani/Gypsies began with a Bosnian Serb girlfriend in Vojvodina who primarily kept warning me to be careful every time we were walking around and passed some Gypsies. We once went to Ireland together in 2007, just after Schengen had opened up to some of the Romani, and passed several groups of Gypsies on a bus ride from Dublin to Galway. And each time we passed them, she laughed at what she perceived as ignorance concerning Schengen, namely that she believed that Western Europe would soon be overrun by Romani.

I later had a Slavic Macedonian girlfriend in Skopje. She was poor and decided to live in a cheap part of Skopje that was about 50% Albanian Macedonians and 30% Macedonian Gypsies. While she lived there for about two years, she got to know some local Albanians and Romani as friends (rare for a Slavic Macedonian). At the time I already had some Albanian friends from Kosovo, but it was the first chance I'd ever really had to talk in depth with Gypsies.

And another thing, if Neanderthal DNA makes you automatically superior, then you should know that there are some Africans who actually do have Neanderthal heritage, like the San, the Masaai, and the Afar, just to name a few.

I never said all humans are 100% the exact same, but you can't deny the fact that all human beings alive today are the same species and subspecies. The closest thing we would have to actual subspecies would be isolated populations like Australian Aboriginals and African Pygmies, and even they have a decent amount of non-Aboriginal and non-Pygmy heritage.

Back to the Neanderthal point: Neanderthals were roughly as smart as modern humans, despite their larger brains. They were more developed in some parts of their brains than we are, but they were also underdeveloped in certain regions too. We "conquered" them thanks to us having superior numbers, as Neanderthals were never a very large species to begin with. Over time, the Neanderthals who didn't go to war with Homo sapiens bred themselves to extinction, and the last remnants of them died out some 30,000-40,000 years ago in Southern Europe. There is no evidence to suggest that they were 100% more intelligent than us, sorry to disappoint you.

sonikku956 Dont say "Turks" but just Turks because I know you think Turks are mixed but that's like saying Greeks are mixed.

The Greek language came from the Proto-Indo-European homeland in Ukraine/Russia. By means of migrations the Indo-Europeans spread to many regions in the world and assimilated the pre-Indo-European peoples of the regions they settled in. Some regions were settled by many Indo-European tribes, like Kyrgyzstan and Kashmir, but others not so much. Genetic studies show that Greeks barely have ancestry from Indo-Europeans, especially Cretans. What happened is, after 3000 BC the Greek Indo-European tribes who were heavily outnumbered by pre-Greeks imposed their identity and language on the pre-Greeks, who had their own identity and language but lost those due to the assimilation. The modern Greeks are primarily descended from pre-Greeks.

The exact same process happened to Turks. There are two differences : 1. Turks have more Central Asian ancestry than Greeks have Indo-European ancestry 2. Anatolian Turks assimilated and mixed with non-Turks after 1071 while Greeks assimilated and mixed with non-Greeks around 3000-1500 BC. 

The pre Greeks were the Leleges, the Pelasgians, the¬†Cretan Minoans, the¬†Cycladic¬†Telkhines, and the¬†Tyrrhenians. The classical¬†Hellenes¬†emerged as an amalgam of these five peoples mixed with a tiny percentage of Indo-European (Greek).

Joorpi Mannon These are Turkmen : http://www.youngpioneertours.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/11/150_turkmen-national-performance.jpg

Do they look Mongoloid? Don't think so.

What if I told you there are many different types of Turks and Turkic languages, and that Turks have never been entirely Mongoloid?


There are Oƒüuz, Uyghur, Kipchak, Oƒüur and Yakut/Siberian Turks and all differ from each other both genetically and linguistically. Central Asian Turks are not as closely related as one would suggest, there is a big difference between a Turkmen (Oƒüuz) and a Kazakh (Kipchak).

All Turks are a mix of the Caucasoid and Mongoloid races, Turks do not belong to one race, unlike most Subsaharan Africans, East Asians & Native Americans and Europeans. Kipchaks are Turks that have always been more Mongoloid than Caucasoid, while Oƒüuz Turks have always been more Caucasoid than Mongoloid. Genetic studies show Turkmen are 18‚Äì40% Mongoloid or East Asian.

There is a lot of confusion due to this fact. Genetic studies on Turkey's Turks often use ‚ÄúCentral Asian‚Äù and ‚ÄúEast Asian‚Äù interchangeably while they are two distinct things. The Turks seem to have 5‚Äì15% East Asian or Mongoloid ancestry, with peaks as high as 20%, but researchers call this ancestry ‚ÄúCentral Asian‚Äù due to confusion. The Central Asian ancestry of Turks is actually higher than that because of part of our ancestry that is racially Caucasoid but from Central, not West Asia.

Commercial DNA tests also do this. They look at your Mongoloid ancestry and then interpret only that as Central or East Asian. This is why Uzbeks and Turkmen score more West Asia than Central Asia with these DNA tests. They are very faulty and need improvement.

GEDmatch is a site that does not do this but compares your ancestry to that of random individuals from many ethnic groups, including Turkmen. So Caucasoid ancestry from Turkmenistan will be interpreted as Turkmen.

My DNA test told me I am 16% West Asian and 4% Central Asian, GEDmatch tells me I am somewhere between ~13‚Äì22.3% Turkmen. Anatolian Turks are often 50%- 25% Turkmen, while Balkan Turks are often 25%-12.5% Turkmen. Azerbaijani Turks can be anywhere between ~6%-50% Turkmen and many of them have Anatolian Turkish ancestry as well because Selim I sent Shia Turcoman tribes to Iran, which controlled ethnographic Azerbaijan.

Because we still have quite some Turkmen ancestry, many of us look like them. But since we have a lot of non-Turkmen ancestry as well, there are also many people that look like westernmost Asians or Europeans. But looking European does not mean they have no Turkmen ancestry. Your appearance is decided while you are in your early development stages, still in your mothers belly and the way you look is completely random. That is why one sibling can be blue-eyed and blonde, but his sister can be a brunette and brown-eyed. Their looks are different, but their ancestry is the exact same.

My own cousins are like that. One of them is blue eyed, very pale and blond, her sister looks like me; tan, brown-eyed and a brunette. However, both have Central Asian ancestry.

I also want to mention that there are 15 million Turkish citizens like Circassians, Lazes, Albanians, Bosniaks and more that generally do not have Central Asian ancestry and they are very common in Turkey as you can tell by their number. However, they feel Turkish so they also identify as Turkish. That's another reason why Turkey has many White citizens. Most of these Circassians, Albanians, Bosniaks etc. (especially the latter two) settled in West Turkey. Izmir and the Marmara region are full with Albanians and Bosniaks! Turks from Macedonia as well, one neighbourhood, a quite big one too, is almost entirely inhabited by Turks from Macedonia.

My mom's family also lives there.. and we are also Turks from Macedonia!

Bottom line : There are Turks that look like the Turkmen settlers, and Turks that look more like ancient Anatolians or Europeans, but all have Central Asian ancestry.
